newsitem.title: UK: U.S. stocks rise in London after Boeing news.
newsitem.headline: U.S. stocks rise in London after Boeing news.

text.p: U.S. stocks were broadly higher in London on Monday and brokers were looking for a strong start on Wall Street in the wake of Boeing Co's $13.3 billion offer to acquire McDonnell Douglas Corp.
News of the merger, which would create a mammoth aerospace and defense firm, was expected to lift investor sentiment in an increasingly jittery market, brokers said.
"The market likes these mega takeover stories. Wall Street will definitely open better," said one London broker.
Shares in McDonnell Douglas were indicated $13 higher at $65, while shares in Boeing Co climbed $5-1/2 to $102-1/4 in London.
At 1043 GMT, the March S&P 500 futures contract was up 1.70 points to 738.10 on Globex, while the March 30-year Treasury bond futures contract rose 10/32 at 113-18/32.
"Shares are firmer, bonds are up and we've got this takeover news," the broker said. "I think we could see the Dow up 15 to 20 points at the start."
Dealers said the market could be influenced later today by the November figures on capacity utilization and industrial production, due for release at 1415 GMT.
Yet few expect the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee meeting, which starts Tuesday, to result in a change in monetary policy.

Coca Cola Co shares added $1/4 to 48-1/8 in London after press reports said the soft drink giant's introduction of a new bright green soda in the U.S. next month could be its biggest soft drink launch since diet Coke.
Coca Cola's new drink will compete directly with Pepsi Co's Mountain Dew. Pepsi shares, one of the few decliners, shed $1/8 to $29.
Technology shares bounced in London after Friday's broad decline. Shares in International Business Machines firmed $3/8 to $152-3/4.
Intel Corp shares, which lost $4-1/2 in New York on Friday, rebounded $1/2 to $132-7/8. Shares in Texas Instruments added $1/4 to $65-3/4, while shares in Digital Equipment rose $1/4 to $39-1/4.
